facts.fact: Bugzilla was originally created in 1998 by Terry Weissman for the Mozilla project to track bugs in the Netscape browser.
The name 'Bugzilla' is a portmanteau of 'bug' and 'Godzilla', reflecting its ability to handle large-scale bug tracking.
Major organizations like Mozilla, Red Hat, NASA, Linux Kernel, GNOME, KDE, and Apache have used Bugzilla for bug tracking.
Bugzilla was one of the first major open-source bug tracking systems available on the web.
Bugzilla pioneered many features now standard in issue trackers, including dependency tracking and duplicate bug detection.
The project has been actively maintained for over 25 years, making it one of the longest-running open-source projects.
The Firefox browser project has tracked over 2 million bugs in Bugzilla during its development history.
Bugzilla pioneered the use of web-based bug tracking when most systems were still client-server applications.
Mozilla was created from the open-sourcing of Netscape Navigator in 1998, one of the most significant events in open-source history.
The Mozilla mascot is a red panda (often mistaken for a fox), not the Godzilla-like creature many assume from the name.
Mozilla Firefox was codenamed 'Phoenix' and then 'Firebird' before settling on Firefox due to trademark issues.
The Mozilla project directly led to the creation of Firefox, Thunderbird, and influenced the development of Chrome and modern web standards.
Bugzilla's bug #1 in the Mozilla database was filed in 1998 and read 'test bug for new database'.
Mozilla coined the term 'browser chrome' to refer to the user interface elements surrounding web content, which Google later adopted for their browser name.
The original Netscape source code release that birthed Mozilla was over 1 million lines of code.
Mozilla's Gecko rendering engine powered not just Firefox but also early versions of numerous other browsers including Netscape, Flock, and SeaMonkey.
Bugzilla has been used to track bugs for hardware projects, not just software, including the Mars rovers at NASA.
Mozilla Foundation's revenue peaked at nearly $500 million annually, primarily from search engine partnerships with Google and later Yahoo and others.
The original Mozilla Application Suite included a web browser, email client, HTML editor, and IRC chat client all in one package.
Bugzilla's influence was so significant that Microsoft's internal bug tracking system was reportedly inspired by it.
Mozilla hired the world's first dedicated security response team for an open-source browser project in the early 2000s.
The 'Mozilla' name comes from 'Mosaic Killer', a reference to the dominant Mosaic browser that Netscape aimed to surpass.
Bugzilla was used to coordinate the massive browser compatibility testing effort when Firefox 1.0 launched in 2004.
Mozilla's decision to split the browser from the suite and create Firefox (then called Phoenix) in 2002 was initially controversial within the community.
Some Bugzilla installations have been continuously running since the late 1990s with databases containing over 20 years of bug history.
Mozilla created Rust programming language, which has since been adopted by Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and is now used in the Linux kernel.
The Firefox 1.0 launch in 2004 was supported by a crowdfunded full-page ad in The New York Times, a first for open-source software.
Bugzilla's architecture influenced the design of GitHub's issue tracking system and many other modern bug trackers.
